p: Anopheles mosquitoes are the vectors of human malaria, which causes at least 400,000 deaths and 200 million cases per year [ 1]. Approximately 90% of malaria deaths occur in sub-Saharan Africa, 7% in South-East Asia and 2% in the Eastern Mediterranean Region, with children under five years of age the most affected. More than 480 species of Anopheles have been described worldwide and about 70 of these are responsible for human malaria transmission, with about 40 regarded as the dominant malaria vector species [ 2, 3].
